ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Oxidation kinetics for Zircaloy-4 with different surface preparation oxidised in 400°C steam.
SEM backscattered cross-section images of metal-oxide region for samples of Zircaloy-4 after 111 days oxidation in 400°C steam.
Metal-oxide interface roughness at different stages of oxidation, resulting from surface preparation and the oxidation process.
Effect of surface profile on the calculations for oxide thickness after 111 days oxidation.

head.ce:title: Observation of the effect of surface roughness on the oxidation of Zircaloy-4

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a

ce:list-item.ce:para: Samples of Zircaloy-4 with four different surface profiles were oxidised in 400̊C steam (autoclave) for up to 275 days.
After ∼84 days oxidation there are clear differences in the weight gain.
Samples with a rougher initial surface finish demonstrated increased rates of oxidation.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Zirconium alloys are used as fuel cladding in light water reactors. Surface preparation techniques that might impair oxidation resistance would limit the lifetime of the cladding and therefore prevent higher burn-up of fuels. The work presented here investigates the impact of surface roughness on the oxidation kinetics of Zircaloy-4 in 400°C steam for exposures up to 275 days. The work shows well defined differences in oxidation kinetics between sample preparations following ∼84 days oxidation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and image analysis of samples in cross section allows for an assessment of the variation in surface roughness between samples at different stages of oxidation.

ce:section.ce:para: Zirconium alloys are used to encapsulate nuclear fuel in pressurised and boiling water reactors. They provide a protective barrier between the fuel and either high temperature water or steam environment. Oxidation of the cladding can often be a limiting factor in the lifetime of the fuel. Therefore, it is important to ensure that all efforts are made to improve corrosion resistance and enable better predictive capabilities of the corrosion process. For many materials, surface finish has an impact on the oxidation behaviour. Chao et al. showed that, in spite of stress relief, oxide spallation was observed during high temperature oxidation of MA956 (aluminium alloy) that had been ground artificially with grit paper. Numerical analysis suggested that this was an effect of oxidation induced localised stresses perpendicular to the metal-oxide interface above roughness peaks [1].

The situation for zirconium alloys is not so clear and experimental evidence, available in the literature, is limited and contradictory. Mardon et al. prepared, by grinding, two different surface finishes on stress-relieved Zircaloy-4. After 3 days of oxidation in steam at 400°C, samples with greater surface roughness displayed a thicker oxide [2]. Jeong et al. oxidised roughened samples of recrystallised Zircaloy-4 in an autoclave for 24h in steam at 500°C. Weight gain analysis indicated increased oxide thickness with coarser surface finish. Jeong et al. also observed that a polished sample exhibited a thinner oxide than that of a chemically etched sample [3]. For the work by both Mardon et al. and Jeong et al., stress relief does not appear to have been carried out. This opens up the possibility that the observations were affected by the residual stress and microstructural changes induced in the near surface substrate.

Sumerling et al. oxidised samples of stress relieved and recrystallised Zircaloy-2 in a steam generating heavy water reactor. Samples were finished with either pickling or belt grinding, followed by pre-filming in a 400°C autoclave to give an oxide thickness around 1–2μm. Subsequent in-reactor tests displayed no significant difference in oxide thickness between pickled and ground finishes [4]. This would appear to indicate that the enhanced oxidation reported by Jeong et al. and Mardon et al. was due to residual stress or damage to the substrate rather than surface geometry. However, work carried out by Kuwae et al. gives contradictory results. Samples of Zircaloy-2, with different precipitate densities, were roughened with different grades of grit paper. Half of the samples were annealed for 2h at 577°C prior to oxidation in 500°C steam for 24h. XRD analysis of both sets of samples indicated compressive stresses in the range of −192MPa to −337MPa in the metal surface after roughening, which was completely removed in half of the samples by the stress relief anneal. Precipitate density was found to have the greatest impact on oxidation kinetics, with the oxide being much thicker on samples with lower densities and presumably larger second phase particles. Increased oxidation with increasing roughness was only observed in annealed samples [5]. Given that this paper highlights the impact of precipitate density on corrosion resistance it does raise the question of how the stress relief and annealing parameters impact precipitate density, and how this could influence corrosion resistance. In addition, the high temperature steam oxidation resulted in the formation of nodules, which is not typically seen during corrosion testing in 360°C primary water or indeed during in-reactor performance.

The aim of the present study is to understand the long-term effect of surface roughness on oxidation of Zircaloy-4 after a stress relief anneal has been carried out. Analysis includes assessment of weight gain to define oxidation kinetics, and cross-section SEM with image analysis.

The material used here was recrystallised Zircaloy-4 sheet, with a composition of 1.24wt%-Sn, 0.17wt%-Fe, 0.1wt%-Cr, <0.01wt%-Nb, <0.01wt%-Ni, supplied by Westinghouse. This was cut into coupons with dimensions of 30mm×16mm×0.66mm, and four different surface preparations were applied to create a range of surface profiles. Three preparations involved grinding with P80, P240 and P800 silicon carbide paper in the transverse direction. The fourth preparation involved pickling in concentrated hydrofluoric acid, followed by a very short polish with colloidal silica to remove any white zirconium fluoride residue.

Samples were subsequently stress relieved in a low pressure Argon environment at 540°C for 4h. Based on the work presented in [6], this was considered sufficient to relieve any residual stresses. Although purging of the chamber was significant, samples were still found to form a pre-film oxide ∼1μm thick. Oxidation tests of samples were carried out subsequently in 400°C steam at a pressure of ∼10.3MPa for up to 275 days, with weight gain being calculated at ∼28 day intervals. This temperature was used in order to avoid nodular corrosion, observed at temperatures >450°C [7], and ideally to create an oxide microstructure and morphology similar to that formed in 360°C water but with faster corrosion kinetics. Oxide thicknesses were defined from weight gain measurements using a conversion of 15mg/dm2=1μm [8].

Samples were removed from test for characterisation following 0 days oxidation (i.e. after heat treatment), 111 days and 275 days of oxidation. These samples were mounted in cross-section, followed by grinding and polishing with colloidal silica prior to examination. The cut faces of the cross-section samples were perpendicular to the transverse direction i.e. the direction of the surface grinding. Analysis of the oxide and metal-oxide interface was carried out using FEI Quanta 200 and Quanta 650 scanning electron microscopes (SEM). Images were taken in back-scattered electron mode to maximise contrast between metal, oxide and mounting resin. In order to gain quantitative information on the metal-oxide interface, 20 images were taken across the metal-oxide region of each sample, covering a total length of ∼1.5mm.

An image analysis script previously developed at AMEC, Risley with the Enthought EPD Python package was used to carry out quantitative image analysis of the metal-oxide region. The use of this image analysis script has been detailed in [8]. The defined profile has been used to assess the impact of surface roughness on surface area and therefore oxide thickness based on weight gain (Section 3.2.1). Using a first order least square method to remove the form, and a Gaussian filter to remove the waviness, it was also possible to calculate the root mean square (Rq) of the surface/interface roughness (Section 3.2.2).(1)Rq=1N∑i=1Nyi2where y is the interface height (μm) at a given point, taken at N number of intervals across the interface.

Fig. 1 shows the oxide thicknesses plotted against time for samples with different surface finishes. For all surface finishes an oxide layer ∼1μm thick is shown at zero days due to the pre-film created during the heat treatment process. For exposures up to 84 days and ∼5.5μm (±5%) of oxide growth, there does not appear to be any significant effect of surface preparation. From 111 days onwards differences between the surface finishes become apparent. There is a clear trend towards rougher surfaces generating thicker oxides, with the pickled samples showing the thinnest oxides overall.

Image analysis was carried out for samples after initial heat treatment, 111 days oxidation, and finally 275 days oxidation. Fig. 2 shows examples of the oxide and interface for each of the surface preparations after 111 days oxidation. The first feature of note is that the grown oxides appear to contain layers of lateral cracks similar to those found in oxides formed during autoclave testing in water at 360°C [9–11]. This is an important feature as the formation of layers of lateral cracks has been associated with the development of oxidation induced interface roughness, transition and acceleration in the corrosion kinetics [8,12,13]. The implication is that although accelerated, the oxidation observed at 400°C should develop via a similar mechanism to that observed at lower temperatures. Although some perpendicular cracks were observed above peaks on samples roughened with P80 grit paper, they did not appear to penetrate through to the interface. It is important to note that none of the analysed samples exhibited any evidence of nodular corrosion.

The oxide thickness is calculated using the weight gain and surface area. Artificially changing the surface profile will modify the surface area and calculated oxide thickness. SEM images of samples removed after 111 days oxidation were used to define the change in surface profile length with variation in applied roughness. The profile lengths extracted from the images were then used to modify the length of the sample and therefore the surface area. Table 1 shows the original oxide thicknesses after 111 days oxidation, the modified oxide thicknesses based on the surface profile length and the percentage difference. Results show a maximum decrease in the oxide thickness of 4% when using a surface which accounts for roughness. Comparing the change in oxide thickness between different surface finishes indicates a variation of less than 1%. As such, the impact of the variation in the profile length on the calculated oxide thickness is considered to be insignificant. In addition, if the differences in weight gain were only due to differences in surface area, rougher samples would be expected to demonstrate thicker oxides at the earliest stages of oxidation.

Cross-sectional preparation of samples allows assessment of the metal–oxide interface roughness after heat treatment and its evolution following 111 & 275 days of oxidation. Characterisation of the roughness was carried out using the root mean square (Rq) of the interface height (Eq. (1)). The results are presented in Fig. 3, with the error bars defined by the standard error. It can be seen that after the annealing heat treatment (0 days oxidation) there is a correlation between grit paper roughness and the roughness of the interface/surface based on the Rq parameter. After 111 days oxidation, the interfaces of all samples, except those ground with P80 grit paper, have increased in roughness. Samples with the lowest initial surface roughness demonstrate the largest increases in interface roughness. Results indicate that after 275 days oxidation the samples are approaching similar levels of roughness.

Most zirconium alloys exhibit cyclical, approximately cubic corrosion kinetics separated by transition points when tested at 360°C in water [9–11]. It has been previously reported that interface roughness increases up to transition, at which point a layer of lateral cracks form [8,12,14]. For recrystallised Zircaloy-4 sheet, the transition points and layers of lateral cracks typically occur every ∼2μm of oxide growth [9,15,16]. Kumar et al. oxidised recrystallised Zircaloy-4 in 400°C steam and found transition occurred after ∼33 days and 2μm of oxide growth [17]. Fig. 1 shows that after 111 days of oxidation the oxide exhibits a thickness of ∼6μm, and SEM analysis (e.g. Fig. 2) indicates that these oxides are starting to form a third layer of lateral cracks. The implication is that after 111 days oxidation these samples are going through the third transition, and that each transition is occurring in ∼37 days periods. Hence, measuring the weight gain every ∼28 days did not allow for detailed characterisation of the cyclical corrosion kinetics.

The initiation sites of the lateral cracks have been previously observed to occur largely above undulation peaks, potentially due to the formation of out-of-plane tensile stress [12,13,18–20]. Geometrically, these second order undulations have amplitudes of the order of ∼0.2μm, and are separated by distances of the order of ∼1μm [11,12]. It has also been observed that a first order interface roughness develops during oxidation, with peaks separated in the range of 7–15μm [11]. However, it is not clear if these first order undulations impact oxidation. Qualitative assessment of the SEM images (e.g. Fig. 2) indicated that this is also the case for the samples oxidised during these experiments.

Following ∼84 days exposure, differences in the corrosion rates for the different surface roughnesses become noticeable, with the differences continuing to increase with continued exposure (Fig. 1). If each surface condition oxidised uniformly, all samples should increase in roughness by approximately the same amount due to the development of first and second order interface undulations. However, Fig. 3 demonstrates that this is not the case. Instead, samples with a rougher surface exhibit either a lower increase in roughness or an absolute reduction in roughness after 111 days oxidation. After 275 days oxidation, most of the samples have converged in terms of the interface roughness. This would suggest preferential corrosion of peaks and/or restricted corrosion of troughs. One theory is that preferential corrosion of peaks could occur due the increased surface/interface area of a peak leading to greater oxygen absorption into the metal substrate. However this would not account for the differences in bulk weight gain as the troughs would exhibit a reduced surface/interface area and therefore exhibit reduced oxidation. In addition, this would not account for the delay in divergence of oxidation kinetics.

When analysing the effect of surface roughness on oxidation of other materials, it has been observed that cracking in the oxide and accelerated oxidation occurs above metal peaks [1,21,22]. For an idealised undulation with a thin oxide relative to the radius of curvature, a simple Laplace equation has indicated that when the oxide is under biaxial compression an out-of-plane tensile stress will increase above the roughness peaks as the oxide thickness increases [22–24]. Based on literature, the oxide biaxial compressive stresses averaged between the monoclinic and tetragonal phases can be up to 2GPa [11,18,25–27]. As such, the introduction of surface roughness should introduce out-of-plane stresses that will accelerate the lateral crack formation, which occurs as a result of the normal oxidation process. It is also possible that the generation of localised tensile stress above undulation peaks could open the metal lattice accelerating oxidation in these regions.

The yield strength of Zircaloy-4 at around 400°C is of the order of ∼130MPa [28]. Previous work has shown manufactured yttria stabilised tetragonal zirconia to demonstrate fracture strengths in the range of 555–745MPa [29,30]. The manufactured zirconia samples reported in these publications are larger and contain much larger defects than thin oxide films. As such, it is likely they will demonstrate lower fracture strengths when compared with thin oxide films. With such a difference between yield strength for metal and oxide, any generated tensile stresses should be relaxed by yielding of the substrate before fracture of the oxide. The oxidation process has been seen to cause deformation [31]. However, oxygen is known to diffuse into the underlying metal [32] which results in solid solution hardening [34]; a 4at.% increase of oxygen has been shown to increase the yield strength of zirconium by ∼100MPa at around 400°C [33]. If out-of-plane stresses above peaks do increase with increasing oxide thickness [22–24], and hardening of the metal substrate is controlled by the level of oxidation, this could explain why a distinctive effect of surface roughness on oxidation kinetics is only observed after 84 days oxidation.

ce:list-item.ce:para: After ∼84 days oxidation in 400°C steam samples of Zircaloy-4 with different surface roughness start to demonstrate differences in weight gain with initially rougher surfaces showing enhanced oxidation.
The difference in weight gain continues to increase with oxidation over the remaining test duration.
SEM image analysis indicates a link with preferential corrosion of peaks in surface roughness.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The authors would like to thank the EPSRC for funding of the Nuclear EngD studentship (Platt) and an EPSRC Leadership Fellowship EP/I005420/1 (Preuss). In addition, top up funding from AMEC is greatly appreciated. Thanks also go to Steve Armitage at AMEC for support with sample preparation. Finally, thanks go to Westinghouse for supplying the material.
